title: 111_s4028
content: Erin's Law, also known as the Erin Maxwell Memorial Grants Act, provides grants in memory of Erin Maxwell. Congress acknowledges the importance of child safety and notes that five children die daily from abuse and neglect in the US. Between 2001 and 2007, 10,440 children died from abuse and neglect, with many cases being underreported. States receive allegations of child abuse involving millions of children annually, highlighting the need for well-trained child protective services workers. Establishment of Grant Program under Part B of title IV of the Social Security Act to enhance child safety. The Erin Maxwell Memorial Grant Program, established under Part B of title IV of the Social Security Act, aims to enhance child safety through grants. The Erin Maxwell Memorial Grant Program, established under Part B of title IV of the Social Security Act, aims to enhance child safety through grants. Definitions in this section include eligible applicants, child protective services workers, and Indian tribes or tribal organizations. The Secretary has the authority to award grants. The Secretary has the authority to award grants on a competitive basis to eligible applicants for hiring child protective services workers. Applicants must submit an application with a long-term strategy to reduce caseloads, improve response times to abuse allegations, and enhance training. The Secretary awards grants to eligible applicants for hiring child protective services workers to improve training, qualifications, and interagency communication processes related to child abuse or neglect. Applicants must describe activities, explain the need for funds, coordinate with other initiatives, hire workers with funds, and plan to gradually increase cost-sharing. The eligible applicant must maintain records of child abuse or neglect referrals in accordance with confidentiality provisions. Units of local government have an additional condition for funding eligibility. Units of local government must meet additional conditions to be eligible for funding under the Treatment Act. They must demonstrate that the state has fulfilled specific requirements of the Child Abuse Prevention and Treatment Act. Funds awarded cannot be used to replace other sources of funding, and there is a limit on how much can be used to hire child protective services workers unless a waiver is granted. Matching funds are required for hiring costs. The grant program under the Treatment Act requires a 75 percent non-Federal contribution for hiring child protective services workers, with the Secretary having the authority to waive this requirement. Grants are divided equally between areas with populations exceeding 150,000 and those with populations of 150,000 or less. The Secretary must establish regulations within 180 days of enactment, and $50,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year.
